sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of environmental event occurring in a region
message_1: A certain region has been experiencing heavy rainfall on 30% of the days in a year. What is the probability that it will rain on exactly 90 days in this particular year?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(x) = (nCx) * (p^x) * (q^(n-x))

where:
- P(x) is the probability of exactly x successes (rainy days) in n trials (days in a year)
- nCx is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time (also written as C(n, x) or "n choose x")
- p is the probability of success (rainy day) on a single trial (30% or 0.3)
- q is the probability of failure (non-rainy day) on a single trial (70% or 0.7)
- n is the total number of trials (days in a year, which is 365)
- x is the number of successes (rainy days, which is 90)

Plugging in the values, we get:

P(90) = C(365, 90) * (0.3^90) * (0.7^(365-90))

First, we need to calculate C(365, 90), which is the number of ways to choose 90 rainy days out of 365 days:

C(365, 90) = 365! / (90! * (365-90)!)
C(365, 90) = 365! / (90! * 275!)

Now, we can calculate the probability:

P(90) = C(365, 90) * (0.3^90) * (0.7^275)

So, the probability that it will rain on exactly 90 days in this particular year is approximately 6.94%.
